repnme.cdata!:
Georgia - Institution Building Credit,
            Rehabilitation Credit, First and Second Structural
            Adjustment Credits, First and Second Structural Adjustment
            Technical Assistance Credits, and Energy Sector Adjustment
            Credit Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The audit conveys mixed results compared
            with the Implementation Completion Report's (ICR)
            ratings, as follows: while ratings concur regarding the
            Institution Building Credit (IBC), and the First Structural
            Adjustment Technical Assistance (SALTA) Projects of
            satisfactory outcome, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts, it downgrades the
            Rehabilitation Credit (RCP) project outcome from highly
            satisfactory to satisfactory, upgrading its sustainability
            to substantial; downgrades the Structural Adjustment Credit
            (SAL) Project outcome to moderately unsatisfactory, with
            likely sustainability, but with modest institutional
            development impacts; and, downgrades the Second Structural
            Adjustment Credit (SALII) Project outcome to unsatisfactory,
            and modest institutional development impacts. Ratings of the
            Energy Sector Adjustment Credit (ESAC) Project concur on
            satisfactory outcome and likely sustainability, but the
            audit upgrades institutional development impacts to
            substantial, and, on the Second Structural Adjustment TA
            (SALTAII) Project outcome is downgraded to moderately
            satisfactory, and modest institutional development impacts,
            although sustainability is also likely. Lessons indicate
            that Georgia's weak governance severely limits the
            country's ability to create conditions conducive to
            economic development, and the effective use of development
            assistance, and, that for a country which experienced
            economic collapse, it is incumbent that the Bank give high
            priority to prompt measures that can directly mitigate
            conditions for the poorest. Furthermore, turnover on the
            country team limited program effectiveness, diminishing the
            continuity of the program, and probably constraining the
            Economic and Sector Work (ES W) that was performed,
            suggesting a more robust, timely ESW program would have been
            beneficial to the design of the reform program, while the
            turnover among policy officials hindered reform progress.

694272.trustfund:
TF031481-GEORGIA - REHABILITATION LOAN,TF027103-PHRD - ENTERPRISE
            REHABILITATION PROJECT,TF020347-REHABILITATION PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Rehabilitation Credit in Georgia. The
            main objective of the Credit was to support Georgia's
            economic reform program which set out to restore
            macroeconomic stability, promote growth, and improve living
            standards. Other objectives were to: (a) provide budgetary
            support to maintain the level of basic public expenditures
            (in particular for wages and the social safety net); (b)
            provide foreign exchange to finance critical imports; (c)
            improve the functioning of the foreign exchange market; and
            (d) provide a framework for financial assistance from other
            donor agencies. The performance of the Bank was
            satisfactory. The performance of the Government of Georgia,
            the borrower has been highly satisfactory. The outcome of
            the project is rated as highly satisfactory. The key lessons
            learned were: (i) strong Government commitment and an active
            and open policy dialogue are essential for success; (ii)
            providing adequate and timely institutional support for the
            implementation of reforms boosts the probability of success
            for economies in transition; (iii) desperate situations
            often afford the greatest possibilities for change; (iv)
            areas that are part politically sensitive, such as land
            reform in Georgia, it is important not to underestimate the
            political difficulties and to begin broad discussions early
            on with all parties involved, particularly the ultimate
            decision makers; and (v) in Georgia substantial attention
            was given to social concerns very early on in the reform process.

18153184.admreg: Europe and Central Asia,Europe and Central Asia
18153184.subsc: Gen agr/fish/for sec,Pension Administration,Banking,Central government administration,Trade
18153184.theme: Other financial and private sector development,State-owned enterprise restructuring and privatization,Regulation and competition policy,Macroeconomic management,Debt management and fiscal sustainability
18153184.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Economic management

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objective of the Rehabilitation
            Credit Project is to support the Government's economic
            reform program aimed at restoring macroeconomic stability
            and at promoting the resumption of growth and improvement in
            living standards. The reform program comprises three sets of
            policies: 1) those aimed at reducing and redefining the role
            of the public sector in the economy; 2) those that foster
            the development and increase the efficiency of markets; and
            3) those that maintain a minimum social safety net through
            improved targeting of benefits. Among the key reforms are
            price and trade liberalization, phasing out of the state
            order system, restructuring of the Government sector,
            privatization, private sector development, and improved
            targeting of social benefits. Other objectives of the credit
            are to: provide budgetary support to maintain the level of
            basic public expenditures, in particular for wages and the
            social safety net;  provide foreign exchange for the
            purchase of critical imports; improve the functioning of the
            foreign exchange market; and provide a framework for
            financial assistance from other donor agencies.
